title: Isaiah Chapter 57 Quiz - Multi-Level
description: An enhanced quiz on Isaiah chapter 57 with Easy, Medium, Hard, and Theological levels. Each level has 15 carefully crafted questions. Choose your difficulty and dive in!

easy.title: Isaiah Chapter 57 Quiz - Easy Level
easy.description: Perfect for beginners! Test your basic knowledge of Isaiah Chapter 57.

questions.question: According to Isaiah 57:1, what happens to the righteous?
questions.correctAnswer: The righteous perisheth
questions.explanation: Isaiah 57:1 states, 'The righteous perisheth, and no man layeth it to heart.'

questions.question: Isaiah 57:2 says the righteous shall enter into what?
questions.correctAnswer: Peace
questions.explanation: Isaiah 57:2 says, 'He shall enter into peace: they shall rest in their beds.'

questions.question: Who does Isaiah call the 'sons of the sorceress' in Isaiah 57:3?
options: The seed of the adulterer and the whore
questions.correctAnswer: The seed of the adulterer and the whore
questions.explanation: Isaiah 57:3 states, 'But draw near hither, ye sons of the sorceress, the seed of the adulterer and the whore.'

questions.question: According to Isaiah 57:5, what are the people enflaming themselves with?
questions.correctAnswer: Idols under every green tree
questions.explanation: Isaiah 57:5 says, 'Enflaming yourselves with idols under every green tree.'

questions.question: Where did they offer sacrifices as mentioned in Isaiah 57:7?
options: Upon a lofty and high mountain
questions.correctAnswer: Upon a lofty and high mountain
questions.explanation: Isaiah 57:7 states, 'Upon a lofty and high mountain hast thou set thy bed: even thither wentest thou up to offer sacrifice.'

questions.question: In Isaiah 57:9, what did the people do to debase themselves?
options: Sent their messengers far off and did debase themselves even unto hell
questions.correctAnswer: Sent their messengers far off and did debase themselves even unto hell
questions.explanation: Isaiah 57:9 says, '...didst send thy messengers far off, and didst debase thyself even unto hell.'

questions.question: Isaiah 57:13 describes what happens when one cries to their companies for help?
options: The wind shall carry them all away
questions.correctAnswer: The wind shall carry them all away
questions.explanation: Isaiah 57:13 states, 'When thou criest, let thy companies deliver thee; but the wind shall carry them all away.'

questions.question: Who does the high and lofty One dwell with according to Isaiah 57:15?
options: Him that is of a contrite and humble spirit
questions.correctAnswer: Him that is of a contrite and humble spirit
questions.explanation: Isaiah 57:15 says, 'I dwell in the high and holy place, with him also that is of a contrite and humble spirit.'

questions.question: True or False: Isaiah 57:16 says God will contend forever and always be wroth.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Isaiah 57:16 states, 'For I will not contend for ever, neither will I be always wroth.'

questions.question: According to Isaiah 57:18, what will God do for the one who has gone astray?
questions.correctAnswer: Heal him and restore comforts
questions.explanation: Isaiah 57:18 says, 'I have seen his ways, and will heal him: I will lead him also, and restore comforts unto him and to his mourners.'

questions.question: What does God create according to Isaiah 57:19?
questions.correctAnswer: The fruit of the lips
questions.explanation: Isaiah 57:19 states, 'I create the fruit of the lips; Peace, peace to him that is far off, and to him that is near.'

questions.question: According to Isaiah 57:20, the wicked are compared to what?
options: The troubled sea when it cannot rest
questions.correctAnswer: The troubled sea when it cannot rest
questions.explanation: Isaiah 57:20 says, 'But the wicked are like the troubled sea, when it cannot rest.'

questions.question: True or False: Isaiah 57:21 states there is peace for the wicked.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Isaiah 57:21 states, 'There is no peace, saith my God, to the wicked.'

questions.question: Fill in the blank from Isaiah 57:14: 'Cast ye up, cast ye up, prepare the ______, take up the stumblingblock out of the way of my people.'
questions.correctAnswer: way
questions.explanation: Isaiah 57:14 says, 'prepare the way, take up the stumblingblock out of the way of my people.'

questions.question: True or False: Isaiah 57:11 says God held his peace even of old and people feared Him not.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Isaiah 57:11 states, 'have not I held my peace even of old, and thou fearest me not?'

medium.title: Isaiah Chapter 57 Quiz - Medium Level
medium.description: Ready for more? Apply biblical truths from Isaiah Chapter 57 to real-life situations.

questions.question: A fellow believer is grieving the loss of a righteous friend. Based on Isaiah 57:1-2, what biblical truth would you share about their passing?
options: The righteous are taken away to avoid coming evil and enter into peace.
The righteous suffer long before they are taken away.
The righteous are punished for their sins before death.
The righteous are forgotten by God after death.
questions.correctAnswer: The righteous are taken away to avoid coming evil and enter into peace.
questions.explanation: Isaiah 57:1-2 teaches that the righteous perish quietly and are taken away from coming evil to enter into peace and rest, walking in uprightness.

questions.question: How does Isaiah 57:3-4 describe those who are rebuked, and what warning does it give about their character?
options: They are called children of transgression and a seed of falsehood.
They are praised for their faithfulness.
They are described as humble servants of God.
They are rewarded for their generosity.
questions.correctAnswer: They are called children of transgression and a seed of falsehood.
questions.explanation: Verses 3-4 warn that those rebuked are offspring of sin and falsehood, emphasizing the consequences of turning away from God and living in deception.

questions.question: What sinful practice is condemned in Isaiah 57:5 related to idolatry and its consequences?
options: Burning incense to idols and sacrificing children in valleys.
Only worshipping God in high places.
Offering sacrifices in the temple alone.
questions.correctAnswer: Burning incense to idols and sacrificing children in valleys.
questions.explanation: Isaiah 57:5 condemns idolatry symbolized by offerings under green trees and the tragic sacrifice of children in valleys, highlighting the gravity of turning to false gods.

questions.question: In Isaiah 57:6-7, what is the response of God toward the offerings made to idols and the places chosen for sacrifice?
options: He questions whether He should receive comfort from them, pointing out their futility.
He accepts them as pleasing sacrifices.
He encourages more offerings in those places.
He remains silent about the offerings.
questions.correctAnswer: He questions whether He should receive comfort from them, pointing out their futility.
questions.explanation: Verses 6-7 illustrate God's rejection of idol worship, questioning the value of sacrifices made to stones and high places, showing such acts cannot comfort Him.

questions.question: A believer is tempted to compromise their devotion by seeking approval from others. According to Isaiah 57:8-9, what warning does the passage provide?
options: They are warned against making covenants with others and debasing themselves, which leads away from God.
They are encouraged to seek new alliances for strength.
They should enlarge their influence by popular support.
They are told to hide their faith to avoid persecution.
questions.correctAnswer: They are warned against making covenants with others and debasing themselves, which leads away from God.
questions.explanation: Isaiah 57:8-9 warns against unfaithfulness, showing how making covenants with others rather than God leads to spiritual downfall and debasement.

questions.question: How does Isaiah 57:10-11 describe the attitude of the wicked toward their ways and God?
options: They are weary but do not admit there is no hope and do not fear God.
They repent deeply and seek God's mercy.
They trust God fully and find peace.
They fear God and change their ways.
questions.correctAnswer: They are weary but do not admit there is no hope and do not fear God.
questions.explanation: Verses 10-11 describe the wicked as exhausted by their path but refusing to acknowledge hopelessness or remember God, demonstrating stubbornness and fearlessness.

questions.question: What does Isaiah 57:12-13 teach about trusting in one's own works versus trusting in God?
options: Works will not profit, but trusting in God leads to possession of the land.
Works alone guarantee inheritance without trust in God.
Trusting in others is better than trusting in God.
Relying on wind and vanity is the path to success.
questions.correctAnswer: Works will not profit, but trusting in God leads to possession of the land.
questions.explanation: These verses emphasize that human righteousness and works are insufficient, and only trust in God secures inheritance and stability.

questions.question: According to Isaiah 57:14, what practical spiritual action are believers encouraged to take for their community?
options: Prepare the way and remove stumbling blocks for God's people.
Isolate themselves from others to avoid sin.
questions.correctAnswer: Prepare the way and remove stumbling blocks for God's people.
questions.explanation: Verse 14 calls believers to actively prepare and clear the way, symbolizing spiritual renewal and support for the community's journey.

questions.question: How does Isaiah 57:15 describe God's relationship with the humble and contrite spirit?
options: God dwells with the humble to revive their spirit and heart.
God ignores the humble and only honors the proud.
God punishes the humble for their weaknesses.
God only speaks to the mighty and strong.
questions.correctAnswer: God dwells with the humble to revive their spirit and heart.
questions.explanation: Verse 15 highlights God's dwelling with those who are humble and contrite, promising revival and restoration.

questions.question: A believer feels overwhelmed by God's discipline. Based on Isaiah 57:16-18, what encouragement can you offer about God's character in discipline?
options: God does not contend forever and will heal and restore the repentant.
God will always be angry and never forgive.
God ignores repentance and lets suffering continue indefinitely.
questions.correctAnswer: God does not contend forever and will heal and restore the repentant.
questions.explanation: Isaiah 57:16-18 assures that God's wrath is not eternal and that He heals those who repent and restores comfort to mourners.

questions.question: How does Isaiah 57:19 encourage believers about the peace God offers to those near and far?
options: God creates peace and promises healing to all who come to Him.
Peace is reserved only for the righteous born in Israel.
Peace cannot be found through God.
Only the near receive peace, not the distant.
questions.correctAnswer: God creates peace and promises healing to all who come to Him.
questions.explanation: Verse 19 speaks of God creating peace and extending it universally, promising healing both to those near and far.

questions.question: Based on Isaiah 57:20-21, what is the described condition of the wicked, and what does this imply about their inner state?
options: The wicked are restless like a troubled sea and have no peace.
The wicked find peace and rest easily.
The wicked are calm and content inside.
The wicked are protected and secure.
questions.correctAnswer: The wicked are restless like a troubled sea and have no peace.
questions.explanation: Verses 20-21 illustrate the wicked as turbulent and unsteady, lacking peace because of their sinful condition.

questions.question: True or False: According to Isaiah 57:1, the death of the righteous is often unnoticed or not deeply considered by others.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Isaiah 57:1 states that the righteous perish and no one lays it to heart, indicating their loss is often unrecognized or unappreciated.

questions.question: True or False: Isaiah 57:15 teaches that God only dwells with those who are proud and self-sufficient.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Isaiah 57:15 clearly says God dwells with the contrite and humble, not the proud, to revive their spirits.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: Isaiah 57:13 says, "When thou criest, let thy companies deliver thee; but the _____ shall carry them all away."
questions.correctAnswer: wind
questions.explanation: Verse 13 uses the imagery of wind carrying away the companies, showing their inability to save compared to trusting God.

hard.title: Isaiah Chapter 57 Quiz - Hard Level
hard.description: Challenge yourself with deep analysis and cross-biblical connections from Isaiah Chapter 57.

questions.question: According to Isaiah 57:1, what is the reason the righteous perish unnoticed?
options: No man layeth it to heart
They are punished for their sins
They are cast out by the community
questions.correctAnswer: No man layeth it to heart
questions.explanation: Isaiah 57:1 states that the righteous perish, and no man layeth it to heart, meaning their passing goes unconsidered by others.

questions.question: What does Isaiah 57:2 say about the state of the righteous after death?
options: They will be judged with fire
questions.correctAnswer: They shall enter into peace
questions.explanation: Isaiah 57:2 describes the righteous entering into peace and resting in their beds, each walking in uprightness.

questions.question: In Isaiah 57:3, who does the prophet call to draw near?
questions.correctAnswer: Sons of the sorceress
questions.explanation: Isaiah 57:3 calls the sons of the sorceress, the seed of the adulterer and the whore, to draw near, indicting those involved in idolatry and moral corruption.

questions.question: What accusation is made against the people in Isaiah 57:4?
options: They are children of transgression and seed of falsehood
They are faithful to their covenant
questions.correctAnswer: They are children of transgression and seed of falsehood
questions.explanation: Isaiah 57:4 declares the people as children of transgression and seed of falsehood, highlighting their rebellion and deceitfulness.

questions.question: What horrific practice is mentioned in Isaiah 57:5 as part of the idolatrous worship?
options: Slaying children in the valleys under the rocks
questions.correctAnswer: Slaying children in the valleys under the rocks
questions.explanation: Isaiah 57:5 condemns the act of child sacrifice under every green tree and in valleys under the cliffs, a practice associated with pagan worship in the ancient Near East.

questions.question: Which metaphor does Isaiah 57:6 use to describe the people’s portion?
options: Among the smooth stones of the stream
In the fertile fields of the land
questions.correctAnswer: Among the smooth stones of the stream
questions.explanation: Isaiah 57:6 uses the metaphor of smooth stones of the stream to describe the people's portion, indicating their idolatrous offerings and false security.

questions.question: What does Isaiah 57:8 reveal about the people's covenant?
options: They made a covenant with others than God
They remained faithful to God's covenant
They renewed the covenant at the temple
questions.correctAnswer: They made a covenant with others than God
questions.explanation: Isaiah 57:8 indicates that the people discovered themselves to others and made a covenant with them, showing unfaithfulness to God.

questions.question: According to Isaiah 57:9, to what extent did the people debase themselves?
questions.correctAnswer: Even unto hell
questions.explanation: Isaiah 57:9 states that the people debased themselves even unto hell, indicating complete degradation in their pursuit of alliances and idolatry.

questions.question: True or False: Isaiah 57:11 suggests that the people feared God and remembered Him in their hearts.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Isaiah 57:11 questions whom the people feared, noting they lied and did not remember God nor lay it to heart, indicating a lack of fear and remembrance.

questions.question: What promise is given to those who put their trust in God in Isaiah 57:13?
options: They shall possess the land and inherit the holy mountain
They will be cast out with the wind
questions.correctAnswer: They shall possess the land and inherit the holy mountain
questions.explanation: Isaiah 57:13 promises that those who trust in God will possess the land and inherit His holy mountain, contrasting with the futility of trusting in other companies.

questions.question: Isaiah 57:15 describes God as dwelling with whom?
questions.correctAnswer: The contrite and humble spirit
questions.explanation: Isaiah 57:15 declares that God dwells with the contrite and humble spirit to revive them, emphasizing His presence with the lowly.

questions.question: What reason does Isaiah 57:16 give for God not contending forever?
options: Because the spirit should fail before Him
questions.correctAnswer: Because the spirit should fail before Him
questions.explanation: Isaiah 57:16 states God will not contend forever as the spirit should fail before Him and the souls He has made, showing divine patience.

questions.question: In Isaiah 57:18, what does God promise to do for those He has seen?
questions.correctAnswer: Heal, lead, and restore comforts
questions.explanation: Isaiah 57:18 promises God will heal, lead, and restore comforts to those whose ways He has seen, highlighting His restorative mercy.

questions.question: What is the 'fruit of the lips' created by God according to Isaiah 57:19?
questions.correctAnswer: Peace
questions.explanation: Isaiah 57:19 states that God creates the fruit of the lips, which is peace, indicating the blessing extended to both near and far.

questions.question: Isaiah 57:20 uses what natural imagery to describe the wicked?
options: Like the troubled sea that cannot rest
questions.correctAnswer: Like the troubled sea that cannot rest
questions.explanation: Isaiah 57:20 likens the wicked to a troubled sea that cannot rest, whose waters cast up mire and dirt, symbolizing unrest and impurity.

theological.title: Isaiah Chapter 57 Quiz - Theological Level
theological.description: Deep biblical theology from Isaiah Chapter 57 that unites all believers. Explore foundational truths about God, creation, and humanity.

questions.question: According to Isaiah 57:1, why is the death of the righteous often overlooked by people?
options: Because no one considers that the righteous is taken away from the evil to come
Because the righteous die in secret
Because the people rejoice at their passing
Because the righteous are not esteemed in society
questions.correctAnswer: Because no one considers that the righteous is taken away from the evil to come
questions.explanation: Isaiah 57:1 states that the righteous perish and no one lays it to heart, not considering that they are taken away from coming evil. This reflects the biblical theme of God's protective removal of the righteous from judgment (cf. 2 Corinthians 5:8; Psalm 116:15; Revelation 14:13; John 14:1-3).

questions.question: What does Isaiah 57:2 say happens to the righteous after death?
options: They enter into peace and rest in their beds
They return to earth as spirits
questions.correctAnswer: They enter into peace and rest in their beds
questions.explanation: Isaiah 57:2 promises that the righteous shall enter into peace and rest, walking in uprightness. This is consistent with biblical teachings on the peace given to the faithful after death (cf. Psalm 23:4-6; John 14:27; Philippians 4:7; Hebrews 4:9-10).

questions.question: In Isaiah 57:3, to whom does the prophet address the words 'ye sons of the sorceress, the seed of the adulterer and the whore'?
options: Those who practice idolatry and spiritual adultery
questions.correctAnswer: Those who practice idolatry and spiritual adultery
questions.explanation: Isaiah 57:3 rebukes those involved in spiritual unfaithfulness, equating them with sorcery and adultery. This imagery aligns with the biblical metaphor of Israel's idolatry as adultery against God (cf. Jeremiah 3:8-9; Ezekiel 16:15-34; Hosea 2:2-13; Revelation 2:20).

questions.question: According to Isaiah 57:5, what heinous acts are associated with idol worship?
options: Enflaming themselves with idols under every green tree and slaying children in the valleys
Building temples on mountains and fasting
Offering sacrifices only at the temple in Jerusalem
questions.correctAnswer: Enflaming themselves with idols under every green tree and slaying children in the valleys
questions.explanation: Isaiah 57:5 condemns the worshippers who burn themselves with idols and commit child sacrifice in valleys, illustrating the abominable practices associated with idolatry (cf. Leviticus 18:21; Deuteronomy 12:31; Jeremiah 7:31; 2 Kings 16:3; Acts 7:43).

questions.question: What does God question about the offerings made to idols in Isaiah 57:6?
options: Should I receive comfort in these offerings?
Are these offerings pleasing to me?
Have these offerings been made at the right time?
Are these offerings sufficient for forgiveness?
questions.correctAnswer: Should I receive comfort in these offerings?
questions.explanation: Isaiah 57:6 questions whether God should find comfort in offerings to idols, emphasizing their futility. This reflects biblical teaching that idolatrous sacrifices are unacceptable (cf. Isaiah 1:11-15; Jeremiah 7:22-23; Hosea 6:6; Amos 5:21-24).

questions.question: According to Isaiah 57:7, where have the people set their bed, symbolizing their place of worship?
options: Upon a lofty and high mountain
In the valley near the river
In the plains under the sun
questions.correctAnswer: Upon a lofty and high mountain
questions.explanation: Isaiah 57:7 describes the setting of their bed on a high mountain, a metaphor for idolatrous worship on elevated places, which the Old Testament condemns (cf. Exodus 34:13; Deuteronomy 12:2; 2 Kings 17:10-12; Ezekiel 6:3-6).

questions.question: In Isaiah 57:8, what covenant is made that indicates unfaithfulness to God?
options: A covenant with others besides God, symbolizing spiritual adultery
A covenant with the priests of Israel
A covenant with foreign nations for protection
A covenant to keep the law strictly
questions.correctAnswer: A covenant with others besides God, symbolizing spiritual adultery
questions.explanation: Isaiah 57:8 reveals that people have made a covenant with others, not God, representing spiritual unfaithfulness or adultery against God (cf. Hosea 1:2; Jeremiah 3:6-10; Ezekiel 16:32-38; James 4:4).

questions.question: What does Isaiah 57:9 say about the people's efforts to gain favor through ointments and perfumes?
options: They sent messengers far off and debased themselves even unto hell
They were accepted by God for their offerings
They gained great honor among nations
questions.correctAnswer: They sent messengers far off and debased themselves even unto hell
questions.explanation: Isaiah 57:9 describes how the people's attempts to gain favor through perfumes and messengers only led to their humiliation and spiritual debasement, aligning with biblical warnings against self-effort for acceptance (cf. Isaiah 66:3; Proverbs 21:27; Romans 3:20; Galatians 2:16).

questions.question: What is the attitude of the people regarding hope, as described in Isaiah 57:10?
options: They found the life of their hand and were not grieved
They confessed their sins and repented
They acknowledged there was no hope
questions.correctAnswer: They found the life of their hand and were not grieved
questions.explanation: Isaiah 57:10 shows that despite weariness, the people did not declare 'there is no hope' because they trusted in their own efforts ('the life of thine hand'), indicating spiritual blindness and self-reliance (cf. Psalm 146:3; Jeremiah 17:5; Proverbs 3:5-6; Romans 7:18).

questions.question: In Isaiah 57:11, what is God’s response to the people's fear and lying?
options: God held his peace even of old, yet they did not fear Him
God gave them signs to repent
questions.correctAnswer: God held his peace even of old, yet they did not fear Him
questions.explanation: Isaiah 57:11 reveals that God was silent and patient in the past, but the people neither remembered Him nor feared Him, highlighting divine longsuffering and human stubbornness (cf. Psalm 78:38; Lamentations 3:31-33; Romans 2:4; Hebrews 10:26-31).

questions.question: According to Isaiah 57:12, what will be the outcome of the people's righteousness and works?
options: They will be accepted by God
questions.correctAnswer: They shall not profit them
questions.explanation: Isaiah 57:12 states that the people's righteousness and works will not profit them, emphasizing that self-righteousness without true faith is futile (cf. Isaiah 64:6; Romans 3:20; Ephesians 2:8-9; Titus 3:5).

questions.question: What promise is given in Isaiah 57:13 to those who put their trust in the LORD?
options: They shall possess the land and inherit God's holy mountain
They will be cast away like the wind
They will face judgment without mercy
They will be abandoned by God
questions.correctAnswer: They shall possess the land and inherit God's holy mountain
questions.explanation: Isaiah 57:13 contrasts the futility of trusting others with the promise that those who trust in God will inherit the land and His holy mountain, reflecting the biblical theme of God's covenant blessings (cf. Psalm 37:9-11; Hebrews 11:10; Revelation 21:1-4; Matthew 5:5).

questions.question: In Isaiah 57:15, how is God described in relation to the contrite and humble spirit?
options: God dwells with the contrite and humble to revive their spirits
God ignores the contrite and humble
God judges the contrite and humble harshly
God distances Himself from the humble
questions.correctAnswer: God dwells with the contrite and humble to revive their spirits
questions.explanation: Isaiah 57:15 reveals God's attribute of holiness and His intimate presence with the humble and contrite, reviving their spirits. This aligns with biblical teachings on God's nearness to the brokenhearted (cf. Psalm 34:18; Matthew 5:3; James 4:6; 1 Peter 5:5).

questions.question: What does Isaiah 57:16 teach about God's patience and anger?
options: God will not contend forever, nor always be wroth
God's anger is eternal and unchanging
questions.correctAnswer: God will not contend forever, nor always be wroth
questions.explanation: Isaiah 57:16 emphasizes God's patience and mercy, stating He will not be angry forever, consistent with Scripture portraying God's longsuffering (cf. Exodus 34:6-7; Psalm 103:8-12; Lamentations 3:22-23; 2 Peter 3:9).

questions.question: How does Isaiah 57:18 describe God's action toward the one smitten for covetousness?
options: God will heal him, lead him, and restore comforts
God will punish him without mercy
questions.correctAnswer: God will heal him, lead him, and restore comforts
questions.explanation: Isaiah 57:18 reveals God's restorative work toward the repentant sinner, showing divine mercy and healing, consistent with biblical themes of forgiveness and restoration (cf. Psalm 147:3; Jeremiah 30:17; John 10:27-28; 1 John 1:9).
